document.title: AP® Macroeconomics COURSE AND EXAM DESCRIPTION

8F683FC7BBBF43AFBA80711D52034CA5.description:
Central banks can influence the domestic
interest rate in the short run, which in turn will
affect net capital inflows.

2E13DFAD0E7B4F9E975F370917884BE9.description:
In an open economy, differences in real
interest rates across countries change the
relative values of domestic and foreign
assets. Financial capital will flow toward the
country with the relatively higher interest
rate. [See EK MKT-4.E.2 and EK MEA-4.A.6 for
explanations of the impact on the loanable
funds market and on net exports.]

741FE7BBC29445669BC7528B2F9A1E7A.description:
Explain (using graphs as
appropriate) how differences
in real interest rates across
countries affect financial
capital flows, foreign
exchange markets, and
loanable funds markets.

D14CABF51934475DAE2D855716FE366C.description:
The interaction of buyers and sellers exchanging the currency of one country for
the currency of another determines the equilibrium exchange rate in a flexible
exchange market and influences the flow of goods, services, and financial capital
between countries.

C3C8ABA3632944BE8B1949C53AC5919D.description:
Real Interest Rates
and International
Capital Flows

D6EC3F242DDF46CAB0C0F181E6B923C7.description:
Factors that cause a currency to depreciate
cause that country’s exports to increase
and its imports to decrease. As a result, net
exports will increase. [See EK MOD-2.A.3
and EK MOD-2.H.1 for explanations of the
effect of changes in net exports on aggregate
demand and the resulting effects on output,
employment, and the price level.]

5AE600450B9C4B7DAE871226362ADB04.description:
Factors that cause a currency to appreciate
cause that country’s exports to decrease and
its imports to increase. As a result, net exports
will decrease.

5A02D42A051246628F68AF05AE803585.description:
Explain (using graphs as
appropriate) how changes
in the value of a currency
can lead to changes in a
country’s net exports and
aggregate demand.

1C6341425B2347AEAF3B94FC41D81DA3.description:
The interaction of buyers and sellers exchanging the currency of one country for
the currency of another determines the equilibrium exchange rate in a flexible
exchange market and influences the flow of goods, services, and financial capital
between countries.

0752E68FCE7B43C9A89295DB4BAA6E70.description:
Changes in the
Foreign Exchange
Market and Net Exports

0D4D41FF762A48F09CD03BB20599BA49.description:
Monetary policy can influence aggregate
demand, real output, the price level,
and interest rates, and thereby affect
exchange rates.

77D6EB02AF6B4BDFA6F8CEE122246133.description:
Fiscal policy can influence aggregate demand,
real output, the price level, and exchange rates.

8E45553698B84F2889713B41B00D6A9D.description:
Factors that shift the demand for a currency
(such as the demand for that country’s goods,
services, or assets) and the supply of a
currency (such as tariffs or quotas on the other
country’s goods and services) change the
equilibrium exchange rate.

147484F7446547C7BA38A0AE28F03B37.description:
a. Explain (using graphs
as appropriate) the
determinants of currency
demand and supply.
b. Explain (using graphs as
appropriate) how changes
in demand and supply
in the foreign exchange
market affect the
equilibrium exchange rate.

D72915CB7A454A308BEA151B3DA974DB.description:
The interaction of buyers and sellers exchanging the currency of one country for
the currency of another determines the equilibrium exchange rate in a flexible
exchange market and influences the flow of goods, services, and financial capital
between countries.

DC8EA10F86CE4FC0B11FBEAE351DFB48.description:
Effect of Changes in
Policies and Economic
Conditions on the
Foreign Exchange Market

883E844DA25140EAAF201F09BC0A0A3F.description:
Disequilibrium exchange rates create surpluses
and shortages in the foreign exchange
market. Market forces drive exchange rates
toward equilibrium.

092619D352BB42548CAE07E53685E3D7.description:
Explain (using graphs as
appropriate) how exchange
rates adjust to restore
equilibrium in the foreign
exchange market.

26E50BD9F3B04D64AF56BA6DBED05F23.description:
In the foreign exchange market, equilibrium is
achieved when the exchange rate is such that
the quantities demanded and supplied of the
currency are equal.

2567343268A14D1E8A4EE103A919C4DC.description:
Define (using graphs as
appropriate) the equilibrium
exchange rate.

F1037D5B602E43ADB22E845B8D69C37D.description:
The supply of a currency in a foreign exchange
market arises from making payments in other
currencies and shows the positive relationship
between the exchange rate and the quantity
supplied of a currency.

37740EA3D5A149309D4822A964FE6B1D.description:
The demand for a currency in a foreign
exchange market arises from the demand for
the country’s goods, services, and financial
assets and shows the inverse relationship
between the exchange rate and the quantity
demanded of a currency.

80C13BAF1EBA462F80212AA26A1D2B71.description:
a. Define the foreign
exchange market,
demand for currency, and
supply of currency.
b. Explain (using graphs
as appropriate) the
relationship between
the exchange rate and
the quantity of currency
demanded (supplied).

D6A6B7F7471047DFAFC14E84311E5528.description:
The interaction of buyers and sellers exchanging the currency of one country for
the currency of another determines the equilibrium exchange rate in a flexible
exchange market and influences the flow of goods, services, and financial capital
between countries.

671AA14AE76741F7948491268CC510F4.description:
If one currency becomes more valuable in
terms of the other, it is said to appreciate. If one
currency becomes less valuable in terms of the
other, it is said to depreciate.

9EEB1E8D27544A898B90BEFC7975A6A7.description:
In the foreign exchange market, one currency
is exchanged for another; the price of
one currency in terms of the other is the
exchange rate.

738753778DCC46EFB79A264EA07D2305.description:
a. Define the exchange rate,
currency appreciation, and
currency depreciation.
b. Explain how currencies
are valued relative to
one another.
c. Calculate the value of
one currency relative
to another.

D46A56F64CEA46FFBF7FCE24C92165C0.description:
The interaction of buyers and sellers exchanging the currency of one country for
the currency of another determines the equilibrium exchange rate in a flexible
exchange market and influences the flow of goods, services, and financial capital
between countries.

5FB9B7086ADF4786AC6DFE9737CB6D45.description:
Any transaction that causes money to flow into
a country is a credit to its BOP account, and
any transaction that causes money to flow out
is a debit. The sum of all credit entries should
match the sum of all debit entries (CA+CFA=0).

980AE231927043FE98EB5398F05902B0.description:
The balance of payments (BOP) is an
accounting system that records a country’s
international transactions for a particular time
period. It consists of the CA and the CFA.

16997C94156748078F607E8456E5C4AE.description:
The CFA is not always balanced; it may show
a surplus (financial capital inflow) or a deficit
(financial capital outflow).

05BF97AD52504C9EAFA801B5C62850C5.description:
The capital and financial account (CFA) records
financial capital transfers and purchases and
sales of assets between countries.

9EB20CC13B594274A0EBE4910D5B4522.description:
The CA is not always balanced; it may show a
surplus or a deficit. A nation’s balance of trade
(i.e., net exports) is part of the current account
and may also show a surplus or a deficit.

9E31718BF77349848AFC47F04F81AA39.description:
The current account (CA) records net exports, net
income from abroad, and net unilateral transfers.

E4017995ECAB49ADA5AE0C2319E2CA94.description:
a. Define the current
account (CA), the capital
and financial account
(CFA), and the balance of
payments (BOP).
b. Explain how changes
in the components of
the CA and CFA affect a
country’s BOP.
c. Calculate the CA, the CFA,
and the BOP.

874C358E93BC41AB8DF550CAC71A4919.description:
Foreign trade accounting measures the flow of goods, services, and financial capital
between countries.

A8D6650355C24D5BA93C0C776F780637.description:
Open
Economy—
International
Trade and
Finance

263309CA0E7A405DB9E1991C7E43BC51.description:
Supply-side fiscal policies affect aggregate
demand, aggregate supply, and potential
output in the short run and long run by
influencing incentives that affect household
and business economic behavior.

19935E7D04934E60B9C5A38CD021B5D2.description:
Government policies that invest in
infrastructure and technology affect growth.

F5318D344248454BAEFC9B1FF3D1A684.description:
Public policies that impact productivity and
labor force participation affect real GDP per
capita and economic growth.

D3433B31AA70450EAA150FC1774D2DC4.description:
a. Explain (using graphs
as appropriate) public
policies aimed at
influencing long-run
economic growth.
b. Define supply-side
fiscal policies.

453B0BF208884211846ABA2FDF686D8F.description: Authorities and organizations institute policies that affect economic growth.

8E85C9863EB347DAB02C258ECDC5B0AC.description:
An outward shift in the PPC is analogous to
a rightward shift of the long-run aggregate
supply curve. [See LO MOD-2.I]

594155CA7957460FB70BA8ADBB1E1C2A.description:
Explain (using graphs
as appropriate) how the
PPC is related to the
long-run aggregate supply
(LRAS) curve.

B94F650B903542768D409BE05EA250FD.description:
The production possibilities curve (PPC) model is used to demonstrate the full
employment level of output and to illustrate changes in full employment.

818B26683B434D1DAE0E3D0413D5B2DF.description:
The aggregate production function shows that
output per capita is positively related to both
physical and human capital per capita.

CEE70F00202F4411AAEEFBBCA7AC1590.description:
Productivity is determined by the level
of technology and physical and human
capital per worker.

09915CC281FF49E9A75CA63352882AE9.description:
Output per employed worker is a measure of
average labor productivity.

4502689EC6B646A5997803F13B451788.description:
Aggregate employment and aggregate output
are directly related because firms need to
employ more workers in order to produce more
output, holding other factors constant. This is
captured by the aggregate production function.

8419AD5975274405B64E5EFEC39C8125.description:
Economic growth can be measured as the
growth rate in real GDP per capita over time.

F70419E103464FE8AA72602D5545FE7A.description:
a. Define measures
and determinants of
economic growth.
b. Explain (using graphs
and data as appropriate)
the determinants of
economic growth.
c. Calculate (using graphs
and data as appropriate)
per capita GDP and
economic growth.

F5550E86A8F747D6AFBAB00C788B38B2.description:
The economy fluctuates between periods of expansion and contraction in the short
run, but economic growth can occur in the long run.

FE7BE4A9F6544CDF806B9AAD6B5783E6.description:
A potential long-run impact of crowding out is a
lower rate of physical capital accumulation and
less economic growth as a result.

E537FF5FDA5D4663965F8EDD56042FED.description:
Crowding out refers to the adverse effect of
increased government borrowing, which leads
to decreased levels of interest-sensitive private
sector spending in the short run.

F70AB6ED1AC9436889AAFCA5504E3282.description:
A loanable funds market model can be used
to show the effect of government borrowing
on the equilibrium real interest rate and the
resulting crowding out of private investment.
[See MKT-4]

000AFE151D304633AD81EBB73D7AF450.description:
When a government is in budget deficit, it
typically borrows to finance its spending.

756CEA10DCF942C28B7C009D4D97025F.description:
a. Define crowding out.
b. Explain (using graphs
as appropriate) how
fiscal policy may cause
crowding out.

B4B483FA618149CF8E52A28FC1EA2E9E.description: There are long-run implications of monetary and fiscal policy

22E8605043BE4F53A7E49ED9768A0308.description:
A government must pay interest on its
accumulated debt, thus increasing the
national debt and increasingly forgoing using
those funds for alternative uses. [See also
LO POL-3.C on crowding out.]

277E85B92C334709ABB33A680EF0497F.description:
A government adds to the national debt when it
runs a budget deficit.

1B560421CE354C0BB0441992D0FFB3F1.description:
The government budget surplus (deficit) is
the difference between tax revenues and
government purchases plus transfer payments
in a given year.

FC5CEFE3535243E79109E7AB80C28BA7.description:
a. Define the government
budget surplus (deficit)
and national debt.
b. Explain the issues involved
with the burden of the
national debt.

5A907A6FE9954454B5D9EA19F9D912E6.description: There are long-run implications of monetary and fiscal policy

9231934FF2574A9F9F526F9A40E73838.description:
Government Deficits
and the National Debt

9DA36F5FBA33463B988946EC7500C889.description:
In the long run, the growth rate of the money
supply determines the growth rate of the price
level (inflation rate) according to the quantity
theory of money.

45186F57E6934E87848DF537F350C176.description:
When the economy is at full employment,
changes in the money supply have no effect on
real output in the long run.

BC73C4BBD4784AF4B2128D901EE3D017.description:
Inflation (deflation) results from increasing
(decreasing) the money supply at too rapid of a
rate for a sustained period of time.

2F7027D618634CD684C8D60B0D96070E.description:
a. Explain (using graphs
as appropriate)
how inflation is a
monetary phenomenon.
b. Define the quantity theory
of money.
c. Calculate the money
supply, velocity, the price
level, and real output
using the quantity theory
of money.

D6829AA0C8A44B3FB03505974F6F3A69.description: There are long-run implications of monetary and fiscal policy.

7F9C9423C2A741B0A89D0BB66C7715D6.description:
Factors that cause the natural rate of
unemployment to change will cause the
LRPC to shift.

E063938AD8E444359452C0649D572AD2.description:
Supply shocks correspond to shifts
of the SRPC.

861586D318D3482CB452A7439ADBA2E4.description:
Demand shocks correspond to movement
along the SRPC.

1256C59B207742DCB38D12FBE6780833.description:
Explain (using graphs as
appropriate) the response of
unemployment and inflation
in the short run and in the
long run.

4874391D1BC341C7B0C2A481A027DC95.description:
Points to the left of long-run equilibrium
represent inflationary gaps, while points to
the right of long-run equilibrium represent
recessionary gaps.

7DF2F503FF794459A8F68016BA9771BB.description:
Long-run equilibrium corresponds to the
intersection of the SRPC and the LRPC.

8734EAF994A64E23B29D4DF12E7A2436.description:
The long-run relationship between inflation and
unemployment can be illustrated by the longrun Phillips curve (LRPC), which is vertical at the
natural rate of unemployment.

1A971543F32147DA87015AE0F40C7235.description:
An economy is always operating somewhere
along the SRPC.

456CD7E0E2704982AA1D8EC6BBCAFD32.description:
The short-run trade-off between inflation
and unemployment can be illustrated
by the downward-sloping short-run
Phillips curve (SRPC).

DFF96416ADCF47ED8A9E390D4C090803.description:
a. Define (using graphs as
appropriate) the shortrun Phillips curve and the
long-run Phillips curve.
b. Explain (using graphs as
appropriate) short-run and
long-run equilibrium in the
Phillips curve model.

44AC57CBC413466C9011599C7C2D4F65.description:
The Phillips curve model is used to represent the relationship between inflation
and unemployment and to illustrate how macroeconomic shocks affect inflation
and unemployment.

2E700139C27D42568A3A4E40F2129353.description:
A combination of fiscal and monetary policies
can influence aggregate demand, real
output, the price level, and interest rates. [For
additional details on fiscal and monetary policy
actions and how to demonstrate their effects
graphically, see LO POL-1.A and LO POL-1.D.]

BFB1C12CFBA24D84B41E111CECC42BF9.description:
A combination of expansionary or
contractionary fiscal and monetary policies
may be used to restore full employment when
the economy is in a negative (i.e., recessionary)
or positive (i.e., inflationary) output gap.

40BB6F208BCC4CFDB0185F9DCB799E40.description:
Explain (using graphs as
appropriate) the effects
of combined fiscal and
monetary policy actions.

6F637E64F1974D6BBCB9CBCDB948F827.description: Fiscal and monetary policy have short-run effects on macroeconomic outcomes.

720FD4D42B0D4FB1AD35FF892D546B22.description:
Fiscal and Monetary
Policy Actions in
the Short Run

AFC551278D6C4E35BD6EF5030BB1FDEA.description:
Factors that shift the demand (such as an
investment tax credit) and supply (such as
changes in saving behavior) of loanable funds
change the equilibrium interest rate and the
equilibrium quantity of funds.

67AD075E5B1D421789952D1D8CFE3B61.description:
The loanable funds market can be used to
show the effects of government spending,
taxes, and borrowing on interest rates.

75D6861A4D3049ED9400DD4978E9084D.description:
a. Explain (using graphs
as appropriate) the
determinants of demand
and supply in the loanable
funds market.
b. Explain (using graphs as
appropriate) how changes
in demand and supply in
the loanable funds market
affect the equilibrium
real interest rate and
equilibrium quantity of
loanable funds.

712F325C8BD34F758A7BA8CC1A5A801C.description:
Disequilibrium real interest rates create
surpluses and shortages in the loanable funds
market. Market forces drive real interest rates
toward equilibrium.

4C43043E8AFB42A7B8C8988B762E80B1.description:
Explain (using graphs as
appropriate) how real interest
rates adjust to restore
equilibrium in the loanable
funds market.

99478FFCA7C844E1B08A962F307CC0DB.description:
In the loanable funds market, equilibrium is
achieved when the real interest rate is such
that the quantities demanded and supplied of
loanable funds are equal.

82A39BFCB20042099D9B1FF97C16004B.description:
Define (using graphs as
appropriate) equilibrium in
the loanable funds market.

4EA1D143EFF74D9C80A0B0F51556D50C.description:
For an open economy, investment equals
national savings plus net capital inflow.

DF2A82202F1846179A35D0B9B58FC390.description:
In the absence of international borrowing and
lending, national savings is the sum of public
savings and private savings.

61EA3CDD763049D5AB5CDA588F55913E.description:
Define national savings
in both a closed and an
open economy.

A74BD41FBE8148AE8E135D73CBE2FE53.description:
The supply of loanable funds shows the
positive relationship between real interest rates
and the quantity supplied of loanable funds.

483EFBE6D2974C158FBC9181402A7B53.description:
The demand for loanable funds shows the
inverse relationship between real interest rates
and the quantity demanded of loanable funds.

CE2AE4582B7B4A859A3E7843B62FCE55.description:
The loanable funds market describes the
behavior of savers and borrowers.

092F1CE6DAD148C880E9D057B1D8C08E.description:
a. Define (using graphs as
appropriate) the loanable
funds market, demand for
loanable funds, and supply
of loanable funds.
b. Explain (using graphs
as appropriate) the
relationship between the
real interest rate and the
quantity of loanable funds
demanded (supplied).

B703925F58C74BB8BAA4B583026B3674.description:
The interaction of borrowers, who demand loanable funds, and savers, who supply
loanable funds, determines the equilibrium real interest rate.

4C9A8FF7A7E445599293753EE538D3B8.description:
In reality, there are lags to monetary policy
caused by the time it takes to recognize a
problem in the economy and the time it takes
the economy to adjust to the policy action.

C6DD5E2D0E0C46B6BA3F8F4BF4FE1D05.description:
Define why there are lags to
monetary policy.

61B61BAA8F2A4D01B89EDFFC0FFF6E64.description:
A money market model, a reserve market
model, and/or the AD–AS model may be
used to demonstrate the short-run effects of
monetary policy

E82A454AED9A441DB4E5A4CA2CA1B979.description:
Monetary policy can influence interest rates,
aggregate demand, real output, and the price
level. [See also EK MKT-5.E.3 for the effect on
exchange rates.]

8A4E9055E41C4C64AFEDA37E841D94D2.description:
Expansionary or contractionary monetary
policies are used to restore full employment
when the economy is in a negative (i.e.,
recessionary) or positive (i.e., inflationary)
output gap.

B06B63A84A9B40EF86FEF0E7F1F88751.description:
Central banks can influence the nominal
interest rate in the short run, which in turn will
affect investment and consumption. [See also
EK MKT-5.G.2 for the influence on net capital
inflows.] In an economy with limited reserves,
the central bank can influence the nominal
interest rate by changing the money supply. In
an economy with ample reserves, changes in
the money supply do not effectively change
the nominal interest rate; instead, the central
bank can influence the nominal interest rate by
changing its administered interest rates.

8508998928DA40988FBDF64AA965BF7F.description:
Many central banks carry out policy to hit a
target range for an overnight interbank lending
rate, sometimes referred to as the central
bank’s policy rate. (In the United States, this is
the federal funds rate.)

409EEFA0C35446ECB35BA5393A205FD5.description:
When the central bank conducts an openmarket purchase (sale) in an economy with
limited reserves, the effect on the money supply
is greater than the effect on the monetary base
because of the money multiplier.

9A39948E522649A29C5394A5BDEC3EE8.description:
When the central bank conducts an openmarket purchase (sale), reserves increase
(decrease), thereby increasing (decreasing) the
monetary base.

29C6467F1E674EDAB5617A104889E4E2.description:
The tools of monetary policy may include
the central bank’s discount rate and other
administered interest rates (e.g., interest on
reserves), open market operations, and the
required reserve ratio. The tools used and
the way in which they are implemented differ
between economies that have limited reserves
in their banking system and economies that
have ample reserves in their banking system.
(The banking system in the United States has
ample reserves, and the Federal Reserve’s key
policy tool is interest on reserves.)

9ECC07C3A7014049A56EC25588C64004.description:
Central banks implement monetary policies
to achieve macroeconomic goals, such as
price stability.

BC5A2EE4E3D64915BA42C68DB958978E.description:
a. Define monetary policy
and related terms.
b. Explain (using graphs as
appropriate) the shortrun effects of a monetary
policy action.
c. Calculate (using data
and balance sheets as
appropriate) the effects of
a monetary policy action.

EA8EE696047841C0A2F8B41805EA39A1.description: Fiscal and monetary policy have short-run effects on macroeconomic outcomes.

50FC688A5E884D708383F3D6E4F413E7.description:
Factors that shift the demand for money, such
as changes in the price level, and supply of
money, such as monetary policy, change the
equilibrium nominal interest rate.

7753129CE4E84DBB80B27F4F29FA4FF8.description:
a. Explain (using graphs
as appropriate) the
determinants of demand
and supply in the
money market.
b. Explain (using graphs as
appropriate) how changes
in demand and supply in
the money market affect
the equilibrium nominal
interest rate.

CD4FF6AD863B49F480724731FB17CCDA.description:
Disequilibrium nominal interest rates create
surpluses and shortages in the money market.
Market forces drive nominal interest rates
toward equilibrium.

185DD32089904648AB78CE05AD74B933.description:
Explain (using graphs as
appropriate) how nominal
interest rates adjust to
restore equilibrium in the
money market.

CCE529FE18EE4CADB891896C8574BD02.description:
In the money market, equilibrium is achieved
when the nominal interest rate is such that the
quantities demanded and supplied of money
are equal.

0099881F5AFD4972A0C8948D53DC3BCE.description:
Define (using graphs as
appropriate) equilibrium in
the money market.

DE349ED0DAE1475F9FBF0229BE4D4F3E.description:
Given a monetary base determined by a
country’s central bank, money supply is
independent of the nominal interest rate.

40D604B438404BF88D44B2BF36284B42.description:
The demand for money shows the inverse
relationship between the nominal interest rate
and the quantity of money people want to hold.

F180FDD998DD47B0A30291DAA196B178.description:
a. Define (using graphs as
appropriate) the money
market, money demand,
and money supply.
b. Explain (using graphs
as appropriate) the
relationship between the
nominal interest rate and
the quantity of money
demanded (supplied).

34D491A7209B48D0BDA87A73404C9378.description:
In the money market, demand for and supply of money determine the equilibrium
nominal interest rate and influence the value of other financial assets.

26C4A75EE6B64E3CBD6B7A27F1B2100D.description:
The amount predicted by the simple money
multiplier may be overstated because it does not
take into account a bank’s desire to hold excess
reserves or the public holding more currency.

2C91313E7BEA408DA0A28DD83E2E991C.description:
The maximum value of the money multiplier
can be calculated as the reciprocal of the
required reserve ratio.

09C493A73D6B403F8722A3B255CD37F5.description:
The size of expansion of the money supply
depends on the money multiplier.

C06C973C02AF49B89AE0BA6786E9C946.description:
The money multiplier is the ratio of the money
supply to the monetary base.

2A9E03ED57394107A9E0FAAB6FD420E7.description:
Excess reserves are the basis of expansion of
the money supply by the banking system.

9ECB151CE37244B89AD1592175CEFDEB.description:
Banks’ reserves are divided into required
reserves and excess reserves.

303DCF971FF8465C90189855F9E5F557.description:
Depository institutions operate using fractional
reserve banking.

46E1711313CF4A27B9A40FB65178FC8B.description:
Depository institutions (such as commercial
banks) organize their assets and liabilities on
balance sheets.

BA2C9BBD711E497EBA01980CAF4BD4D0.description:
a. Define key terms related
to the banking system
and the expansion of the
money supply.
b. Explain how the
banking system creates
and expands the
money supply.
c. Calculate (using data
and balance sheets
as appropriate) the
effects of changes in the
banking system.

4C46E55D9FE144D18F86A4585C096DD6.description: The banking system plays an important role in the expansion of the money supply

007CBAC217A648A4898DF16DE35ED43D.description:
Banking and the
Expansion of the
Money Supply

6691C656C1DB429E8FABBDCEE597D127.description:
The monetary base (often labeled as M0
or MB) includes currency in circulation and
bank reserves.

D144D1C83EE242E9A970BF1BDBF7C2A8.description:
The money supply is measured using monetary
aggregates designated as M1 and M2.

2EFF0B9C4A1B4343AD6B93BC5E2D681D.description:
Money serves as a medium of exchange, unit of
account, and store of value.

00B03B646D744734A3B62F49D7D0861E.description:
Money is any asset that is accepted as a means
of payment.

7F61DAD1EBE64353ADFD0E4F7C2F8CFA.description:
a. Define money and its
functions.
b. Calculate (using data as
appropriate) measures
of money.

9F94BAB717324DCDB05C20F5AD2C3985.description:
Money makes it possible to compare the value of goods and services, and interest
rates provide a measure of the price of money that is borrowed or saved.

FD38EC7845F04FD6A6658921A353C290.description:
Definition,
Measurement, and
Functions of Money

2D3951D1992C4285B7FFF63EA187B0B7.description:
A real interest rate can be calculated in
hindsight by subtracting the actual inflation
rate from the nominal interest rate.

EE93900820BF4F8A8B82E3879A30530C.description:
Lenders and borrowers establish nominal
interest rates as the sum of their expected real
interest rate and expected inflation.

1F09E3E86F19445989B67E40046938FF.description:
A nominal interest rate is the rate of interest
paid for a loan, unadjusted for inflation.

A261B86B5B354F84BE43334DBE0314AE.description:
a. Define the nominal and
real interest rate.
b. Explain the relationship
between changes in
nominal interest rates,
expected inflation, and
real interest rates.
c. Calculate the nominal and
real interest rate.

CAC814DD40604844A80348116C245EA7.description:
Money makes it possible to compare the value of goods and services, and interest
rates provide a measure of the price of money that is borrowed or saved.

FF73C807435845A7B65050D3AEE5EDC7.description:
The opportunity cost of holding money is the
interest that could have been earned from
holding other financial assets such as bonds.

CCA338996AD540ECA1B8C5C3CFE303BF.description:
The price of previously issued bonds and
interest rates on bonds are inversely related.

A6C3200DBE794793AC2DC44B13DE94B4.description:
Other financial assets people can hold in
place of the most liquid forms of money
include bonds (interest-bearing assets) and
stocks (equity).

4E92FC1CBC71475CAA7875BBC6A76715.description:
The most liquid forms of money are cash and
demand deposits.

0ABC580121604F29A1066EDFDC52813B.description:
a. Define the principal
attributes—liquidity,
rate of return, and risk—
associated with various
classes of financial assets,
including money.
b. Explain the relationship
between the price of
previously issued bonds
and interest rates.

401F632A92E04E1F90C8CCF99D386351.description:
Money makes it possible to compare the value of goods and services, and interest
rates provide a measure of the price of money that is borrowed or saved.

34F2CA5E19F744CAB3B863687A6405AD.description:
Government policies, institutions, or agencies
may also have social service programs whose
transfer payments act as automatic stabilizers.

AF8B8A691A134AFCB0B714BC677890F5.description:
Tax revenues increase automatically as GDP
rises, slowing consumption and preventing the
economy from overheating.

AA783B78AFBA44CDA44920EF6AB49031.description:
Tax revenues decrease automatically as
GDP falls, preventing consumption and the
economy from falling further.

8E61FEA33D28401F8A387A56482F52B2.description:
Automatic stabilizers support the economy
during recessions and help prevent the
economy from being overheated during
expansionary periods.

C18E663BDC014263BDABEB2D55114C3C.description:
a. Define automatic
stabilizers.
b. Explain how automatic
stabilizers moderate
business cycles.

DAA4DBDDCEB64C479B066C517510E25C.description: Fiscal and monetary policy have short-run effects on macroeconomic outcomes.

18876778D041455CAD22AD91058697F9.description:
In reality, there are lags to discretionary
fiscal policy because of factors such as the
time it takes to decide on and implement a
policy action.

40ACFF42FAFF4AA1AE0E681F11DF910A.description:
Define why there are lags to
discretionary fiscal policy.

BAB24B8D67CC4F6ABE0F73053D228C6B.description:
The AD–AS model is used to demonstrate the
short-run effects of fiscal policy.

3345421323614D06AF49D980908C89E6.description:
Fiscal policy can influence aggregate demand,
real output, and the price level. [See also EK
MKT-5.E.2 for the effect on exchange rates.]

7B43963B6B6B455C917413E4EF8FC582.description:
Expansionary or contractionary fiscal policies
are used to restore full employment when the
economy is in a negative (i.e., recessionary) or
positive (i.e., inflationary) output gap.

75BC9A891F3D432AB9B9CD10840955C3.description:
The government spending multiplier is greater
than the tax multiplier.

BA4D61869F404AEF9B080DEDE83E831F.description:
Changes in government spending affect
aggregate demand directly, and changes
in taxes/transfers affect aggregate
demand indirectly.

EAAFC9F7F48447F097046A319AB08DB4.description:
The tools of fiscal policy are government
spending and taxes/transfers.

31257DB57F8943D29CF9A9D193AB660B.description:
Governments implement fiscal policies to achieve
macroeconomic goals, such as full employment.

2E5D95242F7B4C419F62D51C7B1A13A8.description:
a. Define fiscal policy and
related terms.
b. Explain (using graphs as
appropriate) the shortrun effects of a fiscal
policy action.
c. Calculate the short-run
effects of a fiscal
policy action.

29DD9C25E5FF4D86AB6B2CFF977C8BD0.description: Fiscal and monetary policy have short-run effects on macroeconomic outcomes.

72FF740225DE4C7EA38DC5646875B93F.description:
Shifts in the long-run aggregate supply curve
indicate changes in the full-employment level
of output and economic growth.

57D1A9737E9B43BDB413AF1960E0516C.description:
In the long run, in the absence of government
policy actions, flexible wages and prices
will adjust to restore full employment and
unemployment will revert to its natural rate after
a shock to aggregate demand or short-run
aggregate supply. [See EK MEA-1.E.2]

58D852E63AF84D55B742F90977186DB0.description:
Explain (using graphs as
appropriate) the response of
output, employment, and the
price level to an aggregate
demand or aggregate supply
shock in the long run.

7422F4ABA67943068E9A11073437F806.description:
Economists use the aggregate demand–aggregate supply model to represent
the relationship between the price level and aggregate output in an economy
and to illustrate how output, employment, and the price level respond to
macroeconomic shocks.

96658FE6850B4850AE1442012DFDC391.description:
Inflation can be caused by changes in
aggregate demand (demand-pull) or aggregate
supply (cost-push).

55064C8091534499AAFF451D1CAEA644.description:
A positive (negative) shock in SRAS causes
output and employment to rise (fall) and the
price level to fall (rise) in the short run.

65D5FCBB06BD4A4A9D3231B8D9DE8DC1.description:
A positive (negative) shock in AD causes
output, employment, and the price level to rise
(fall) in the short run.

FFF157436C5D4C5B80D9AC6B0D236A03.description:
Explain (using graphs as
appropriate) the response of
output, employment, and the
price level to an aggregate
demand or aggregate supply
shock in the short run.

767D7CDC7B2A461CB31C68462D9AAB46.description:
Economists use the aggregate demand–aggregate supply model to represent
the relationship between the price level and aggregate output in an economy
and to illustrate how output, employment, and the price level respond to
macroeconomic shocks.

6F04CDAD97654204867E0CA3739B802A.description:
Changes in the
AD–AS Model in
the Short Run

9195E078DE064C8780B77DD13DECCF39.description:
The short-run equilibrium output can be at the
full-employment level of output, above it, or
below it, creating positive (i.e., inflationary) or
negative (i.e., recessionary) output gaps.

8E3B450C3B294327BBF64EDC1996DC15.description:
Long-run equilibrium occurs when the AD and
SRAS curves intersect on the LRAS—i.e., at the
full-employment level of real output.

6348D8AB43E540C0BCE5256E3198A9B6.description:
Short-run equilibrium occurs when the
aggregate quantity of output demanded and
the aggregate quantity of output supplied are
equal—i.e., at the intersection of the AD and
SRAS curves.

7C6604BE4D63443EA70164FE62ADD226.description:
Explain (using graphs as
appropriate) the short-run
and long-run equilibrium
price level and output level.

856161D50F3D4DECB8D13004CA9DB985.description:
Economists use the aggregate demand–aggregate supply model to represent
the relationship between the price level and aggregate output in an economy
and to illustrate how output, employment, and the price level respond to
macroeconomic shocks.

D714DD15EDF74A2C97F05F79BE0FE7C0.description:
Equilibrium in the
Aggregate Demand–
Aggregate Supply
(AD–AS) Model

2953B821BFFE40CC8017DB1F50387F08.description:
The LRAS curve is vertical at the full-employment
level of output because in the long run wages and
prices fully adjust.

08D5A036E6BD4075A6093A4FB83DBE32.description:
The LRAS curve corresponds to the production
possibilities curve (PPC) because they both
represent maximum sustainable capacity.
Maximum sustainable capacity is the total
output an economic system will produce over
a set period of time if all resources are fully
employed. [See LO MOD-2.I]

53F204C41C23496D973FD2626E206E63.description:
Define (using graphs as
appropriate) the long-run
aggregate supply
(LRAS) curve.

E91EA8A7673543EB886628625123650D.description:
In the long run all prices and wages are fully
flexible, while in the short run some input prices
are fixed. A consequence of flexible long-run
prices and wages is the lack of a long-run
trade-off between inflation and unemployment.

D47EB3DC0A6544F281053B41DE8022CF.description:
Define (using graphs as
appropriate) the short run
and the long run.

32FE9C33E10F46CDBAB54131ED085418.description:
Economists use the aggregate demand–aggregate supply model to represent
the relationship between the price level and aggregate output in an economy
and to illustrate how output, employment, and the price level respond to
macroeconomic shocks.

688212345F574336B782F518BAD5E462.description:
Moving along the SRAS curve, an increase in
the price level is associated with an increase
in output, which means employment must
correspondingly rise. With the labor force held
constant, unemployment will fall. So, there is
a short-run trade-off between inflation and
unemployment. [See EK MOD-3.A.1]

566735143C584A308DF6F77F718E4A05.description:
Explain (using graphs as
appropriate) how movement
along the SRAS curve implies
a relationship between the
price level (and inflation)
and unemployment.

710183ADB0464896B84D2693E7A4EBF2.description:
Any factor that causes production costs
to change, such as a change in inflationary
expectations, will cause the SRAS
curve to shift.

2BD79C3CA3E2434693F98C4742E6282F.description:
The SRAS curve is upward-sloping because of
sticky wages and prices. [See EK MOD-2.E.1]

0D2D534E14FF4D5697C527D514364D82.description:
The short-run aggregate supply (SRAS) curve
describes the relationship between the price
level and the quantity of goods and services
supplied in an economy.

349B17D14BCB4C01A88936D03F76C2E0.description:
a. Define (using graphs
as appropriate) the
short-run aggregate
supply (SRAS) curve.
b. Explain (using graphs as
appropriate) the slope
of the SRAS curve and
its determinants.

1178B6F9DB484844BBCABF622D41A4F0.description:
Economists use the aggregate demand–aggregate supply model to represent
the relationship between the price level and aggregate output in an economy
and to illustrate how output, employment, and the price level respond to
macroeconomic shocks.

C536585C9D83401FAA1BAAAAFA7B5594.description:
The marginal propensity to consume is the
change in consumer spending divided by the
change in disposable income. The sum of the
marginal propensity to consume and marginal
propensity to save is equal to one.

82178F3E97F04507BC56133B575F6384.description:
The expenditure multiplier and tax multiplier
depend on the marginal propensity
to consume.

1419AE48F0674CBBB1C117E76A4B6378.description:
The tax multiplier quantifies the size of the
change in aggregate demand as a result of a
change in taxes.

FBABF3210CC642809A4317669DC7D09C.description:
The expenditure multiplier quantifies the size
of the change in aggregate demand as a result
of a change in any of the components of
aggregate demand.

ACA91345E259479E8D928BB2D0D935D6.description:
A $1 change to autonomous expenditures
leads to further changes in total expenditures
and total output.

E6A10F7F361949D9896034FDF31E88A5.description:
a. Define the expenditure
multiplier, the tax
multiplier, the marginal
propensity to consume,
and the marginal
propensity to save.
b. Explain how changes in
spending and taxes lead to
changes in real GDP.
c. Calculate how changes in
spending and taxes lead to
changes in real GDP.

E0F9787DE9B344ECB2CEB1531E05B1B4.description:
Economists use the aggregate demand–aggregate supply model to represent
the relationship between the price level and aggregate output in an economy
and to illustrate how output, employment, and the price level respond to
macroeconomic shocks.

D4DFABD5A01446049AB7B6BBC2686696.description:
Any change in the components of aggregate
demand (consumption, investment,
government spending, or net exports) that is
not due to changes in the price level leads to a
shift of the AD curve.

AFE1793CBFA842BBA840488B8BC44D27.description:
The negative slope of the AD curve is
explained by the real wealth effect, the interest
rate effect, and the exchange rate effect.
[See EK MKT-3.A.1]

E52B55C35C9B4FE7B9C7C84E2C2ADDFC.description:
The aggregate demand (AD) curve describes
the relationship between the price level and the
quantity of goods and services demanded by
households (consumption), firms (investment),
government (government spending), and the
rest of the world (net exports).

F0BB47A277764134B3DF2E9A4C224728.description:
a. Define (using graphs as
appropriate) the aggregate
demand (AD) curve.
b. Explain (using graphs as
appropriate) the slope
of the AD curve and
its determinants.

222CB3FF7E9845C59829EB73264EBACB.description:
Economists use the aggregate demand–aggregate supply model to represent
the relationship between the price level and aggregate output in an economy
and to illustrate how output, employment, and the price level respond to
macroeconomic shocks.

271E1CC4255C4D369F775B9238506520.description:
Potential output is also called full-employment
output. It is the level of GDP where
unemployment is equal to the natural rate of
unemployment. [See EK MEA-1.E.2]

499E4D4367524DAD82A661747DA545C6.description:
The difference between actual output and
potential output is the output gap.

B15CECD8697F49B19CB98CD4B169EBA5.description:
The turning points of a business cycle are peak
and trough.

5710532A584644C288097393D39FB3A8.description:
The phases of a business cycle are recession
and expansion.

0019A0D50162458EAA585A8E931FDBD6.description:
Business cycles are fluctuations in aggregate
output and employment because of changes in
aggregate supply and/or aggregate demand.

D84388DE2E7F475AB28213E4C6DA0120.description:
a. Define (using graphs
and data as appropriate)
turning points and phases
of the business cycle.
b. Explain (using graphs
and data as appropriate)
turning points and phases
of the business cycle.

561C0960571C4CC991E0CE154551492F.description:
The economy fluctuates between periods of expansion and contraction in the short
run, but economic growth can occur in the long run.

948EA4073C80461B95FDD9A0F9723D63.description:
Nominal GDP can be converted to real GDP by
using the GDP deflator.

CB8A1352F74646E090D8557310412FB3.description:
One way of measuring real GDP is to weigh final
goods and services by their prices in a base
year. Because this can lead to overstatement of
real GDP growth, statistical agencies actually
use different methods.

5972D3D26A0A407CB43BCDA641678576.description:
Calculate real GDP and the
GDP deflator.

C6A8FBA2BEFD40DE8290E2F5B80B66D9.description:
Nominal GDP measures aggregate output
using current prices. Real GDP measures
aggregate output using constant prices, thus
removing the effect of changes in the overall
price level.

D0171B617F4C4CFD843F5FBF2B1E313B.description:
Nominal GDP is a measure of how much is
spent on output. Real GDP is a measure of how
much is produced.

0312A7CE78DE4C91A8A9FE142571A82C.description:
Define nominal GDP and
real GDP.

A8D67155D8934C678A47E381D21D2C14.description:
An economy’s performance can be measured by different indicators such as gross
domestic product (GDP), the inflation rate, and the unemployment rate.

F0350917FAD540128FAF2C2C3BFE3C83.description:
Unexpected inflation arbitrarily redistributes
wealth from one group of individuals to another
group, such as lenders to borrowers.

E62F31863BA14C738F14095ABDA7FD27.description:
Explain the costs that
unexpected inflation
(deflation) imposes on
individuals and the economy.

5719749A466045E3A0853553ADD005CC.description:
An economy’s performance can be measured by different indicators such as gross
domestic product (GDP), the inflation rate, and the unemployment rate.

B41E91C404C244F6B551FAF3606BF94B.description:
The CPI as a measure of inflation has some
shortcomings, such as substitution bias,
causing it to overstate the true inflation rate.

2E93C216EE46452C82899F0EC06AA36B.description:
Define the shortcomings of
the CPI as a true measure
of inflation.

64E1B7257C7F4F5F9915EB5535BF5EFB.description:
Real variables, such as real wages, are the
nominal variables deflated by the price level.

CCD27AD40BF4491B967E305B0B230C6A.description:
The inflation rate is determined by calculating
the percentage change in a price index, such
as CPI or the GDP deflator.

26BA137D8D6D42CB99D52B3681C3BF76.description:
The CPI measures the cost of a fixed basket of
goods and services in a given year relative to
the base year.

584D0D9E915B4F839970A52DB4E99ED0.description:
The consumer price index (CPI) measures the
change in income a consumer would need in
order to maintain the same standard of living
over time under a new set of prices as under
the original set of prices.

967DB1DA4EC644078F3EB810C354137A.description:
a. Define the consumer
price index (CPI), inflation,
deflation, disinflation,
the inflation rate, and
real variables.
b. Explain how price indices
can be used to calculate
the inflation rate and to
compare nominal variables
over time periods.
c. Calculate the CPI, the
inflation rate, and changes
in real variables.

CD5C276E4F5E47589FDEC4D4D9DE974E.description:
An economy’s performance can be measured by different indicators such as gross
domestic product (GDP), the inflation rate, and the unemployment rate.

CFE5F956227E4145A79B8E69B1A26984.description:
The natural rate of unemployment can
gradually change over time because
of such things as changes in labor
force characteristics.

80A05AB488A04018BB4F06C8F982CCB1.description:
The deviation of the actual unemployment rate
from the natural rate is cyclical unemployment.

A8E5DFFACAB541029FF85EE2769A59EE.description:
The natural rate of unemployment is the
unemployment rate that would exist when
the economy produces full-employment real
output. It is equal to the sum of frictional and
structural unemployment.

5034932427CD4FF4AB3F9D485F31A90F.description:
Economists primarily focus on three types
of unemployment: cyclical, frictional,
and structural.

FA03086480AF4F0099E8A3A24A076900.description:
a. Define the types of
unemployment and
the natural rate of
unemployment.
b. Explain changes in the
types of unemployment.

20915F859D774E07A4E6C5C5F8F0EE65.description:
The measured unemployment rate is often
criticized for understating the level of
joblessness because it excludes groups such
as discouraged workers and part-time workers.

25C3284213304895A916689D100EF3BB.description:
Define the limitations of the
unemployment rate.

32646B81483E4B4086953A595B862935.description:
The labor force participation rate is another
measure of the labor market activity in an
economy. The labor force participation rate is
the percentage of the adult population that is in
the labor force.

654C060E0A6F4B48895D125C3BB6CD72.description:
The unemployment rate is the percentage of
the labor force that is out of work.

AF2D5576904E48D082564884C4B1F96A.description:
a. Define the labor force,
the unemployment rate,
and the labor force
participation rate.
b. Explain how changes
in employment and the
labor market affect the
unemployment rate
and the labor force
participation rate.
c. Calculate the
unemployment rate
and the labor force
participation rate.

F19384EA07D6426AA9A231BE50EDDCB2.description:
An economy’s performance can be measured by different indicators such as gross
domestic product (GDP), the inflation rate, and the unemployment rate.

5E971F0CA1D541CEA2E27B642118B954.description:
GDP is a useful indicator of a nation’s
economic performance, but it has some
limitations, such as failing to account for
nonmarket transactions.

886296A09C7B4873A905036BC36CA919.description:
An economy’s performance can be measured by different indicators such as gross
domestic product (GDP), the inflation rate, and the unemployment rate.

6DEBFEC50FF64653BF4444DBC577BC8B.description:
There are three ways of measuring GDP: the
expenditures approach, the income approach,
and the value-added approach.

C77763F40C9F470EBB1065DECC217CEB.description:
GDP as a total flow of income and expenditure
can be represented by the circular
flow diagram.

32477E87D4A74711BEED531E49E300BB.description:
GDP is a measure of final output of
the economy.

DA8B598D289E4C41A6476501027B61FB.description:
a. Define (using the
circular flow diagram
as appropriate) how
GDP is measured and
its components.
b. Calculate nominal GDP.

197BE67D25CD44D18170702CDFD73931.description:
An economy’s performance can be measured by different indicators such as gross
domestic product (GDP), the inflation rate, and the unemployment rate.

D14712C2A9CB4AA9BFC4E02C56ED0675.description:
Economic
Indicators
and the
Business
Cycle

5DAC40A230434EB8A4ADB736D10BDD91.description:
Changes in the determinants of supply and/
or demand result in a new equilibrium price
and quantity

E498711B483E42F783C4A7380797C674.description:
Explain (using graphs as
appropriate) how changes
in demand and supply
affect equilibrium price and
equilibrium quantity.

9146E735DE7148B98EB2DA3358FECBE7.description:
Whenever markets experience imbalances—
creating disequilibrium prices, surpluses,
and shortages—market forces drive prices
toward equilibrium.

E47B851A26634B759AC6EF11B82DFEEB.description:
a. Define a surplus
and shortage.
b. Explain (using graphs
as appropriate) how
prices adjust to
restore equilibrium
in markets that are
experiencing imbalances.
c. Calculate (using graphs as
appropriate) the surplus
or shortage in the market
experience an imbalance.

2DE3E903BB1B4805847F49AE7EF7744F.description:
Equilibrium is achieved at the price at which
quantities demanded and supplied are equal.

D182EF46895D4C8B9CF5A8A16045E991.description:
Define (using graphs
as appropriate)
market equilibrium.

BB9AFF9875E74A22B5AD16FE59FD764C.description:
In a competitive market, demand for and supply of a good or service determine the
equilibrium price.

4E88D44C045445ED9D07BD5B5BE6745E.description:
Market Equilibrium,
Disequilibrium, and
Changes in Equilibrium

5A8639CB54FB4F2F887261AAB500B885.description:
Factors that influence producer supply, such
as changes in input prices, cause the market
supply curve to shift.

63C51166F6BD4BCAB178CF09C38BE23F.description:
Explain (using graphs
as appropriate) the
determinants of supply.

43FCD090E0474E24AE338312E354D301.description:
The law of supply states there is a positive
relationship between price and quantity
supplied, leading to an upward-sloping
supply curve.

D9A0DA6531F34175964D353765DB0FDE.description:
a. Define (using graphs
as appropriate) the
law of supply.
b. Explain (using graphs
as appropriate) the
relationship between the
price of a good or service
and the quantity supplied.

01DC29546E5D4C4496A22F6551D409BD.description:
In a competitive market, demand for and supply of a good or service determine the
equilibrium price.

DC89B148B3CD425FAF5FA4D77A1F6747.description:
Factors that influence consumer demand, such
as changes in consumer income, cause the
market demand curve to shift.

A3BE5FE1694349ABA1F19F1B603639F9.description:
Explain (using graphs
as appropriate) the
determinants of demand.

6FFE7769B2C54A5B83FCE1DEC6919503.description:
The law of demand states there is an inverse
relationship between price and quantity
demanded, leading to a downward-sloping
demand curve.

5B7054E5A4B5499B978010078B10451A.description:
a. Define (using graphs
as appropriate) the law
of demand.
b. Explain (using graphs
as appropriate) the
relationship between
the price of a good
or service and the
quantity demanded.

E4EE15FA49934C91BC89602CE6EB0BB8.description:
In a competitive market, demand for and supply of a good or service determine the
equilibrium price.

7E0678F5111B47D1B85C722C2A3D0188.description:
Comparative advantage and opportunity costs
determine the terms of trade for exchange
under which mutually beneficial trade
can occur.

CC313A791A7A43CDBF2CC753ABBF97F3.description:
Production specialization according to
comparative advantage results in exchange
opportunities that lead to consumption
opportunities beyond the PPC.

12FD29CD729F49FD9A1D6798A9DD90A6.description:
a. Explain (using data
from PPCs or tables
as appropriate) how
specialization according
to comparative advantage
with appropriate terms
of trade can lead to gains
from trade.
b. Calculate (using data
from PPCs or tables as
appropriate) mutually
beneficial terms of trade.

DA80CCEFAD374E6190716C01FC58932E.description:
Comparative advantage describes a situation
in which an individual, business, or country
can produce a good or service at a lower
opportunity cost than another producer.

7C276A75524B4686A58B29A83A69751D.description:
Absolute advantage describes a situation
in which an individual, business, or country
can produce more of a good or service than
any other producer with the same quantity
of resources.

8550F3563A034FE6AA4DF758A5D833BF.description:
a. Define absolute
advantage and
comparative advantage.
b. Determine (using data
from PPCs or tables as
appropriate) absolute and
comparative advantage.

1FFB8DD602D04E6BB4F1E37A7A99D580.description: Production and consumption increase by engaging in trade.

77A5831E2E98418E9D86E1512B24673C.description:
Comparative
Advantage and
Gains from Trade

C30DEC7CB1274E35848D109B44A70B01.description:
Economic growth results in an outward shift
of the PPC.

DAF4A6037389468A88CAEE036C708133.description:
The PPC can shift because of changes in
factors of production as well as changes in
productivity/technology.

9982F8D83D8743C3963FA4A3C4360795.description:
The shape of the PPC depends on whether
opportunity costs are constant, increasing,
or decreasing.

1771C0AC42774B1FBA6762471EA0D613.description:
The PPC can be used to illustrate the concepts
of scarcity, opportunity cost, efficiency,
underutilized resources, and economic growth
or contraction.

E4FE6EB3B73848288841EFB0D31F06D3.description:
The PPC is a model used to show the tradeoffs
associated with allocating resources.

3BC3EC316FB44A68938EE9248A5150AB.description:
a. Define (using graphs as
appropriate) the PPC and
related terms.
b. Explain (using graphs as
appropriate) how the PPC
illustrates opportunity
costs, tradeoffs,
inefficiency, efficiency,
and economic growth
or contraction under
various conditions.
c. Calculate (using data
from PPCs or tables as
appropriate) opportunity
cost.

4D5348845FD443498771C58C5F73570F.description:
The production possibilities curve (PPC) model is used to demonstrate the full
employment level of output and to illustrate changes in full employment.

40900474769A48FB90C8837C0A25E352.description:
Opportunity Cost
and the Production
Possibilities Curve (PPC)

DF74719536BC4B5CBC2957E69D36C018.description:
Individuals and societies are forced to make
choices because most resources are scarce.

BE97581544E24998ADB88526F6996F36.description:
The production possibilities curve (PPC) model is used to demonstrate the full
employment level of output and to illustrate changes in full employment.
